title: Is life a thing or an idea? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, I’m speaking from the vantage point that life equals existence and/therefor it’s not something material, measurable, divisible or comparable, therefor it cannot be anything with objective qualities like a thing or an idea. This kind of reasoning derives from an obvious timeless experience and it cannot be understood by reasoning alone… like how do you explain the direct experience of understanding or existence for that matter? It’s something obvious yet at the same time it’s on the limit of reasoning, we’re in existence, life, our minds are made of it, therefor they cannot ever jump out of it, see it and explain it (yet most of us behave as if we’re superior to it and can analyse it… which is hilarious at the end).

I would say an idea, more than a thing. Where do you draw the line between what is alive and what isn't? It's a made up line that doesn't physically exist. All of what we call “life" comes from dust. Life grows out of non-life. So when we call it “life" we're just putting an imaginary line at a certain point in which we deem the thing to now be living. It's all one thing, we could say it's all alive. There is no real seperation between anything. All of what we call “seperate” or “parts" are just ideas because if you get with reality you'll realise that there is zero seperation anywhere, except in the mind.
